headline: Why Morgan Stanley, Citi and other banks are exiting climate alliance
summary: Morgan Stanley (MS), Citigroup (C), Bank of America (BAC), Goldman Sachs (GS), and Wells Fargo (WFC) are among the major banks that left the Net Zero Banking Alliance (NZBA). Yahoo Finance's Banking Reporter David Hollerith joins Asking for a Trend with Josh Lipton to break down what it means for the banking sector heading into a second Trump administration. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Asking for a Trend here. This post was written by Naomi Buchanan.

headline: Morgan Stanley joins exodus from Mark Carney’s net zero banking group
summary: Morgan Stanley has quit Mark Carney’s net zero banking group, joining a broader Wall Street exodus as Donald Trump prepares to re-enter the White House.

headline: Wall Street banks exit climate alliance as Trump 2.0 nears
summary: Some of the biggest lenders in the US are beating a retreat from a UN-backed bank climate group in the final weeks before a new Trump administration prepares to take office.

raw.headline: Wall Street banks exit climate alliance as Trump 2.0 nears
raw.summary: Some of the biggest lenders in the US are beating a retreat from a UN-backed bank climate group in the final weeks before a new Trump administration prepares to take office.

headline: Morgan Stanley to leave sector climate coalition
summary: Investment bank Morgan Stanley said on Thursday it had decided to leave the Net-Zero Banking Alliance, becoming the latest U.S. lender to quit the sector's top global climate coalition.  Despite leaving the NZBA, Morgan Stanley said in a statement that its commitment to helping the world transition to net-zero carbon emissions "remains unchanged".  The decision by Morgan Stanley follows similar moves in recent weeks by Citigroup, Bank of America, Wells Fargo and Goldman Sachs.

headline: 2025 a 'Show Me' Year for Earnings, Says Morgan Stanley's Shalett
summary: -- Lisa Shalett, chief investment officer at Morgan Stanley Wealth, says some of the earnings expectations built into stock prices may just be too ambitious....
